item.title: Covid: Most rules set to end in England, says PM
item.description: Boris Johnson says the success of the vaccine means England can begin to look beyond restrictions.

item.title: PM, Whitty, and Vallance on when they'll wear masks
item.description: Prof Chris Whitty and Sir Patrick Vallance explain the situations in which they'll still use face coverings.

item.title: Covid-19: Germany lifts ban on tourists from UK and Portugal
item.description: People who are fully vaccinated will also not be required to quarantine when they arrive.

item.title: Roberts Buncis: Boy, 15, convicted of knife murder of friend
item.description: Roberts Buncis was stabbed more than 70 times in the attack just two days before his 13th birthday.

item.title: Raducanu retires because of difficulty breathing
item.description: British wildcard Emma Raducanu retires from her Wimbledon fourth-round match after suffering breathing difficulties, ending her fairytale Wimbledon debut.

item.title: Richard Donner: Superman and Goonies director dies aged 91
item.description: Tributes have been pouring in for the director, whose films also included The Goonies and The Omen.

item.title: Vauxhall to build electric vans at Ellesmere Port
item.description: The car manufacturer is expected to confirm plans to make electric vans.

item.title: Georgia: Tbilisi Pride cancelled as far-right protesters burn rainbow flags
item.description: LGBT activists cancel a Pride event after violent far-right protests in Georgia's capital Tbilisi.

item.title: Ice hockey player dies in 4 July firework accident
item.description: Columbus Blue Jackets goaltender Matiss Kivlenieks dies after a "fireworks malfunction" at a Fourth of July party.

item.title: Boris Johnson admits it's ludicrous he's PM, says Cummings
item.description: The former aide launches another attack on the PM, but also defends his decision to work for him.

item.title: Four-day week 'an overwhelming success' in Iceland
item.description: The majority of workers in Iceland now look set to move to shorter hours for the same pay.

item.title: Manchester Arena Inquiry: Ex-GMP officer investigated over evidence
item.description: Ch Insp Dale Sexton is being investigated over his evidence at the Manchester Arena attack inquiry.

item.title: Newspaper headlines: Now or never, says PM, after lockdown ending 'gamble'
item.description: Almost all Tuesday's papers lead with Boris Johnson's plans to end Covid restrictions in England on 19 July.

item.title: Climate change: The craft brewery using algae to cut emissions
item.description: An Australian craft brewery is using microalgae to turn their carbon emissions into oxygen.

item.title: Is busking on TikTok the future?
item.description: Liv Harland live streams herself on TikTok and says she makes a lot more online than on the street.

item.title: London air pollution turned into art to raise awareness
item.description: Marina Vitaglione used a traditional photographic process to create striking images of air pollution in London.

item.title: Bafta-nominated young game designers take on real-world issues
item.description: Bafta's nominees for Young Game Designer of the year tackle important issues for a new generation.

item.title: Boris Johnson: 'If we can't reopen in next few weeks, when will we?'
item.description: Prime Minister Boris Johnson speaks about the final step of England's roadmap out of lockdown.

item.title: Covid: The restrictions-easing dilemma facing Southwold
item.description: People in Southwold, a popular tourist destination, react to the restriction-easing measures.

item.title: My 'lovely' calves: Irish 10-year-old swaps cash prize for herd
item.description: Irish 10-year-old William Woods has been cow-unting his blessings after buying calves with the winnings from a prize draw.

item.title: NHS Covid thanksgiving service: 'They did what they could to save my life'
item.description: A doctor, a patient and a volunteer reflect on Covid-19, as a thanksgiving service is held at St Paul's.

item.title: After Lod violence, Israeli city's residents fear for the future
item.description: Both Jewish and Arab Israelis feel unprotected after intercommunal violence in the Israeli city.

item.title: Covid-19: 'For us it's not freedom day, is it?'
item.description: Their medical conditions mean they are considered vulnerable to Covid. How are they feeling now?

item.title: Riot of cherry blossom reveals new Damien Hirst post-lockdown
item.description: Giant cherry blossom paintings by Damien Hirst contrast with his previous dead animal art.

item.title: India's Covid doctors demand action after attacks
item.description: Doctors are seeking a stringent law to protect them from attacks by angry and frustrated relatives.

item.title: How to get a lucrative job in cybersecurity
item.description: There's a serious shortage of IT security workers, so recruiters are fishing in a bigger pool.

item.title: 'Prison is the safest place for my mum'
item.description: Ex-offenders, experts and support services all want better rehabilitation services in Wales.

item.title: Benefits and disability: 'I'll never cohabit again, to protect myself'
item.description: Some disabled people have been left uncomfortably reliant on partners after benefits were removed.

item.title: Is the use of jetpacks finally about to take off?
item.description: Members of the public can now pay to fly through the air like a superhero.

item.title: Letter from Africa: Lamenting the Algeria-Morocco border closure
item.description: The Morocco-Algeria border has been closed for decades, despite close ties between the people.

item.title: Protests, pet thefts and sex crimes: MPs want changes to the policing bill
item.description: The controversial Policing, Crime, Sentencing and Courts bill is back in the Commons on Monday.

item.title: 'The opportunity to bring happiness for our fans, our nation, is very special'
item.description: England have a "very special opportunity" to make the country happy when they face Denmark in their Euro 2020 semi-final, says Gareth Southgate.

item.title: Anderson takes 1,000th first-class wicket
item.description: James Anderson takes 7-19, including his 1,000th first-class wicket, as Lancashire skittle Kent inside a session for just 74, before wobbling on 108-5.

item.title: Federer & Djokovic ease into quarter-finals in front of bigger crowds on Centre Court
item.description: Eight-time champion Roger Federer follows top seed Novak Djokovic into the Wimbledon quarter-finals as both ease through their last-16 matches.

item.title: Tokyo 2020: 'Players treated like dirt' by Badminton England
item.description: Olympic medallists Chris Langridge and Marcus Ellis say the Badminton England set up is "hostile" and players fear speaking out about their concerns.

item.title: Euro 2020 semi-final - can Spain do a Portugal & can Italy replace Spinazzola?
item.description: Italy and Spain go head to head in a European Championship knockout game for the fourth event in a row - these are the talking points.

item.title: Wimbledon 2021: Ashleigh Barty and Felix Auger-Aliassime in Manic Monday best bits
item.description: Watch the best bits from Wimbledon's Manic Monday including wins for the top seeds, a crowd catch and and epic match on Centre Court.

item.title: Wimbledon 2021: How British teenager Raducanu lit up the first week of Wimbledon
item.description: Watch the best bits from Emma Raducanu's whirlwind first week at Wimbledon as the British teenager impressed at SW19.

item.title: Covid: What's the roadmap for lifting lockdown?
item.description: Boris Johnson has set out government plans for lifting the remaining Covid restrictions in England.

item.title: Covid: Why is social distancing coming to an end?
item.description: The prime minister has announced the next steps for social distancing in England.

item.title: Coronavirus: When can we stop wearing face masks or coverings?
item.description: Wearing a face covering is currently a legal requirement in many places, but rules are changing in England.

item.title: Covid: Should I be working from home or going back to the office?
item.description: The working from home advice in England is set to change on 19 July.

item.title: Covid-19 in the UK: How many coronavirus cases are there in my area?
item.description: Explore the data on coronavirus in the UK and find out how many cases there are in your area.

item.title: Covid: When will I get the vaccine?
item.description: The PM says every adult should have had the chance to be doubled jabbed by mid-September.

item.title: Covid: Will free school meals continue over summer holidays?
item.description: A year on from Marcus Rashford's successful campaign, what is the current situation?

item.title: Lockdown rules: What are the restrictions in your area?
item.description: Use our search tool to find out about coronavirus rules and restrictions where you live.

item.title: What are the rules for travelling to green, amber and red list countries?
item.description: The government is considering allowing double vaccinated adults to avoid quarantine after travel.

item.title: Covid map: Coronavirus cases, deaths, vaccinations by country
item.description: Key maps and charts explaining how the virus has spread around the world.

item.title: 'Coercion and rape': Investigating my yoga school
item.description: Ishleen Kaur was passionate about yoga movement Sivananda, until she found allegations of sexual abuse.

item.title: British Jews' fear and defiance amid record monthly anti-Semitism reports
item.description: Some 460 anti-Semitic incidents were reported to the Community Security Trust from 8 May to 7 June.

item.title: A fake wedding, and a $250,000 scam
item.description: How a British man's dreams of a future with his Ukrainian fiancee ended in financial disaster.
